reviewText: You have to give the creators of GENERATION KILL --Just LOVE that title-- credit. They did an amazing job making a great recrutement show. It is seriously needed now more than ever. It must be assumed the military gave it's full support in the making of this HBO production. Watching GENERATION KILL it should be clear to most viewers being in the Marines means being in a brotherhood, something so many young men are desperate for, and it sure looks like a lot of fun. That GENERATION KILL shows *some* bad stuff that can happen to our "boys" over there only serves to make it all the more exciting. This is where you can be somebody, be part of a group, and be a real man. All those people back home just don't get it and they never will. They have been through something more real, something deeper, something so much more meaningful than anything they could experience back home. If you murder innocent people, don't worry, you were "just doing your job".EDIT (01-04-09):I forgot to add that the the soldier's sunglasses are cool on the GENERATION KILL cover.
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: Besides the action, the humor in traded insults, guy talk, and Marine jabber, is worth the price alone. Outstanding cinematography and story telling.
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: I'm a vet myself though I never had the opportunity to go out to combat, I can tell you that what you see is about as realistic as it gets short of enlisting yourself!! I too was attached to a USMC Battalion out of Camp Pendleton being a Navy Medic, (the marines do not train any for their own) hence the US Navy provides them w/Navy corpsman (medics) Marines have a completely off the charts desire to seek, hunt and destroy instilled through never ending brainwashing that they're indestructible & there is no match even close to being a "Jarhead" The constant questioning of their superior's decisions & orders is pretty much how it remains to present day. They know and accept the fact that they(Marines) will always be the first wave to set foot on enemy ground, & the first to draw blood. Therefore their hesitance following orders that take them away from the front lines, I've seen them, lived w/them & always did my best to patch up the continuous small injuries they all seem to accumulate when not in combat, & spend most of their time & money on contemplating the mysteries of the female gender while sitting on a barstool"I also knew deep down that if I ever found myself under fire during a real military clash, these guys wouldn't think twice about stepping out into the kill zone to retrieve another US soldier they consider one of their own!This movie may come across as being high on profanity and short on respect, but thats the only way to deal with living in a highly dangerous territory. For all their faults (feminist, anti-gay, anti-everything that doesnt have a USMC sticker on) I could not, would not put my life in the hands of any other military enlistee other than USMC!!! Hoooh-Rahhh!!
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: I had read the book Generation Kill so I decided to purchase the dvd box set. After reading other books such as Band of Sisters, Joker One, and One Bullet Away - this movie seems to accurately portray everyday life -- boredom then sheer terror. Some of the actors in this series are actual  RECON Marines who helped the series be as authentic as possible. If you liked or hated Over There - well this series blows that show out of the water in terms of writing and special effects. The acting is incredible - the cast is awesome. The standouts include Alexander Skarsgaard (True Blood) and Stark Sands (incredible actor who we'll hopefully see more of). To say this show is leftist can be seen from some characters but not others as Sgt. Colbert says to Iraqis, "Vote Republican!". Either way I've met people who now want to join the military b/c of the brotherhood b/t the Marines. This show is definitely profane and there are even some offensive moments that I had to fast forward - (the kids writing to the guys) but I still watched it already a dozen times - the funny parts and the action NEVER wear out. Also good extras on the last dvd showing behind the scenes and the "boot camp" the actors had to go thru run by Rudy Reyes and other marines.
summary: Insane, Hilarious, and great Special Effects

We're baby killers!" reminiscent of bad Vietnam movies.The end of the film depicts our heroes watching a "home movie" that shows dead bodies as the song "When the Man Comes Around" plays, and the heroes slowly walk off in self-loathing and disgust.I walked away from this film in disgust, as well.

reviewText: First, let me say the production values were outstanding.  The technicals were great.  Humvees sounded like Humvees and A-10s sounded like A-10s  It was fun to watch but the message behind the series was despicably biased.The officers were presented as incompetents and or sociopathic glory seekers.  Orders were changed and rescinded arbitrarily or enforced with capricious callousness.The equipment was non-existent or shoddy and denied to the front line troops.  The troops were the kind of people you would cross the street to avoid.  Callous baby-killers and crass sexist mysoginists out to 'make their bones'.  The streets were littered with dead children and marines.  One character had some actual human traits and the story revolved around him as the only foundation of sanity.  Amazing we were able to dismantle and army and regime in three weeks with a bunch of twenty year old thugs ill-equipped for the mission.
summary: Dishonest and agenda driven portrayal of our military
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: HBO's seven part miniseries based on Evan Wright's Generation Kill is a brutally honest and realistic depiction of the early days of the invasion of Iraq as told through the eyes of the First Recon Marines. Produced and written by David Simon and Ed Burns who gave us such classic television as The Wire and Homicide the series is not to be missed.The First Recon Marines are preparing to enter Iraq as the show opens. There is a feeling of excitement that comes on the verge of war. After this initial excitement breakdowns occur. There are problems with supplies arriving, there is dissent in the chain of command and there are questions as to orders given. The show ends with the taking of Baghdad but the show leaves its viewer with more questions than overall answers.The series is presented in an in your face manner that may be difficult for some viewers to get into. You are literally dropped into a confusing situation and left to fend for yourself and reach your own conclusions. The acting is first rate along with the entire production. The set features commentaries on six out of seven episodes. There is a discussion with the actual First Recon Marines upon whom the story is based. A thirty minutes making of featurette films in some gaps in the production history. Perhaps the most interesting and telling special feature is a video diary kept by cast member Eric Ladin.This is a mature and brutal examinination of modern American warfare. It may not be for everyone but the series does take its viewers on quite an unforgettable ride.
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: When I first heard about Generation Kill, I expected it to simply be a glamorised version of the Iraq War where it shows everything working smoothly. What I didn't expect was a gritty and true story of the 1st Recon Marines during the first wave of the American invasion of Iraq. It didn't hold back, and honestly I would have hated it if they did. I later found out that this was based on the book written by journalist Evan Wright who followed this company during the initial invasion. I haven't read the book, but from the other stuff I've read I'm lead to believe it keeps true to the novel.The show focuses around the 1st Recon Marines company as a part of the initial invasion of Iraq that eventually overthrew Sadaam Hussein. It shows the true struggles that the marines went through during this invasion as they struggled with supply shortages and conditions. They are joined by Rolling Stones reporter Evan Wright (Book Author) who's there to see what really goes on in the Marine Corps. It's not about Wright or is it even about one particular Marine, it's rather a show about the entire company and their particular personalities.This is the more interesting and disturbing nature of the show. A lot of the soldiers displayed appear to have some real mental problems when it comes to their enthusiasm to kill anything in sight, or just their general views of the Iraqi people. It touches upon the civilian killings and how some order were actually made by the higher ups to kill any Iraqi whether they had weapons displayed or not. On one hand I would say it's wrong to have people with such mental problems i.e. a bit too enthusiastic to kill. On the other hand, if you didn't have these particular individuals then would we even have an army capable enough to fight such a war.Another aspect of the show, aside from the disturbing images or the general crudeness of it all is the irreverent humour displayed. It's not intentional and certainly isn't set up to be hysterical, it simply comes across as that as within the conversations of some of these men, like any chat with friends etc. you always get the odd unintentional classic line. This gives the entire show a well rounded feel and is something to be experienced by everyone. I applaud those who are over in Iraq and Afghanistan as, unfortunately due to my ignorance before this show I didn't know things were so tough.It's an overall great show and another classic creation by HBO. Be warned, however, as it is very graphic in relation to violence and if you're easily offended by strong or racist language then I would advise you stay away.
summary: Gritty & Genuine. The Best War TV Show Ever Created
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: Sure the firefights and comraderie is in here, but the one UNDERLINING, SUBLIMINAL point it makes in each episode is the wontan killing of civilians and collateral damage the US military does in Iraq.  The sheer joy and amusement of the military at the destruction it is causing is harpped on, and on.  I saw the whole serise(except the last episode)and the writers also just love to show men defacating and urinating and shooting civiliand, women, children, structures, etc.; as long as they're showing guns spitting spent shells and having that cool sound of M-16/M14 goin off.I also read the book and it seems the author was also fully engrossed in only recording the civilina casualties.  Each time they came in contact with the enemy, woemen and children were the only ones that got paragraphs and paragraphs of details.Oh and there were Syrians and Iraqi jihadist that got killed also, but you get a sentance and then on to the chilren and innocents getting shredded left and right.  It did happen, I read it on "One Bullet Away" by Nate Fick, the guy featered in Gen. Kill the book and tv series, but come on, give the guys some credit.  By the way, "One Bullet Away" is a waaaay better book than Gen. Kill.  The Gen. Kill authore just like to let you know how many times men in war go use the bathroom.  He also details it over and over and over.  We know guys out there don't have nice restrooms or private bathrooms, okay.  It goes without saying.  But to write about it over and over...  The tv series also likes this aspect of the tale.  You get to see guys butts alomst every 15 minutes.  You sure don't see that on Platoon by Oliver Stone, or even implied on Tour of Duty(the '80s tv series).The brutality of war is shown, but mostly how it affects women and children in the line of fire.  The real bad guys don't get much time in the book or the tv series.  In no way does this compare to Saving Priveate Ryan and Band of Brothers.  Those movies/series were about the heart of the US military, not the heartless ones they are portrayed here.I for one will not be buying it on DVD, nor do I recommend anyone else to do so either.  Unless you like to see the killing of innocents by our incompetent military(which is what the book and series paint our miltary to be).  I did 12 yrs in the US Navy so I know a little about military comraderie.  It's show here, but in a deceitful context.
summary: AVOID AT ALL COST!! Unpatriotic and just plain wrong...
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: First off, I haven't been deployed to Iraq, nor a I a Marine. That being said, I found the series to be very entertaining. Granted, it may or may not be a totally accurate depiction of the attitude of the Marines themselves (there are some sequences that don't strike me as..."characteristic", for lack of a better word, of Marines, or members of any branch for that matter.) That aside, Generation Kill strikes me as being a relatively well done series just a few notches down from Band of Brothers.

reviewText: This is a great show with amazing dialog following the first 30 day for the Iraq War. This is not a documentary but based on one following the First Recon Battalion. This includes lots of extra and its HD cut looks great. Once I started watching it I couldn't stop till I finished them all.
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: _Generation Kill_ is a war story, of course. But it's also a story about who we are. I suppose all good war stories should be. But this one is a rare look at the complex identity of a group of elite men who are, in turns, the products of Marine Corps discipline and MTV self-absorption. Where they might fail to study the philosophical implication of their situations, but there are moments when the characters seem to glow with a zen-style understanding. This is a loving take on the men who fight for us and the tangle of beauty and horror and humor and  absurdity that outlines their experiences doing so.
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: One of the best and relative war shows of the 21st century.  Do yourself a favor and watch it now.

Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: UPDATE: I uploaded a customer image of the Marine jargon used in this series.  It will be very useful to new persons to this series.I'm a big fan of Band of Brothers and The Pacific and I went into Generation Kill hoping for more of the same and I was not disappointed. It's definitely an honest look at modern military activity. When the good guys aren't so good and the bad guys aren't always bad. While it's not as epic as the previously mentioned series it still is a phenomenal production. I love the characters and how you get to see inside them and what motivates them.  It's what I love about the series that HBO produces they generally let you look at the different characters on a very in-depth level. It's what makes all these miniseries so much better than movies because of the character development in my opinion.If you can stand having subtitles very few shows in English benefit as much as GK. The subtitles pick up on a lot of the background chatter plus whatever they use military acronyms it's easier to decipher what they said. Personally I love subtitles whenever I watch the show and I recommend them highly.I watch this series almost yearly and always will pick up funny new things that I didn't notice on previous viewings. I can't recommend this enough especially if you like military movies or video games.The one thing I love about this show is the military jargon and radio chatter that is used often. Now I've seen the series five times and over those repeat viewings I've been able to make out or look up what much of the jargon or terms they use mean. the one thing I love about this show is they don't go into depth to explain what they're talking about they leave that up to the viewer to Google it themselves. So here's a comprehensive list I recommend printing it and using it while you watch the show.556: The diameter bullets in millimeters used by US forces in rifles and light machine guns a.k.a. NATO rounds.Assassin: Radio call sign for first recon's Alpha company; assassin actual is Alpha company's commander Capt. Patterson.AO: Area of operationAOE: Area of engagementAss: Traveling in the company of heavy units like tanks, cobras ectBDA: Battle Damage AssessmentCas Evac: Casualty EvacuationChaos: radio call sign for General MattisCorpsman: Enlisted member of a military medical unit.Cleared hot: Given permission to fire your weapon by a superior.Danger close: Friendly units are within 600 meters of a proposed artillery target.Fire mission: Artillery missionForty Mike-Mike: 40 millimeters; refers to either an individual 40mm self-propelled grenade round or the weapon that launches them, such as the M-19.Glassed:  Observed target with binoculars or rifle scope.Godfather: Call sign of Lieut. Col. Ferrando as well as his battalion in part due to the sound of his voice. NOTE: Godfather often speaks of himself in the third person; instead of saying "I think" he will say "Godfather thinks"Haji: Slang for an IraqiH&S;: The headquarters and supply company responsible for supporting "line companies" or combat units made up of Alpha, bravo and Charlie companies.Helo-hot: Missile fired from a combat helicopter such as an Cobra.Hitman Two One Actual:  Bravo company's second platoon team one leader, Sgt. Colbert. While "Hitman Two One" refers to the entire team, "Actual" means the actual commander. "Hitman two" refers to all of bravo second platoon, but "Hitman Two Actual" is the platoon commander, Lieut. Fick.Hitman Victor: any vehicle and bravo company.Interrogative: Radio code prefacing a questionLAV:  Light Armored VehicleLOD: Line Of DepartureKlicks: KilometersMikes: minutesMSR: Main Supply RouteNJP: Non-Judicial Punishment ie disciplineNVGs: Night Vision GogglesOscar Mike: On the movePec-fours, Pec-thirteens: Night and infrared vision scopes.POG: Person Other than GruntPX: post-exchange storeRaptor: Radio call sign for First Recon's Charlie CompanyROE: Rules of Engagement, rules for engaging civilian targetsRTB: Return to BaseRTO: Radio Telephone OperatorRCT1: Regimental Combat Team 1Shamal: Hellacious wind and dust storms endemic to Iraq.Sit-Rep: Situation report, basically the status on mission or area.SOP: Standard Operating ProcedureStay frosty: Staying sharp, or attentive to the situationT72s: an Iraqi tankVictors: VehiclesWhiskey Tango: white trashSo there you go I hope you enjoy that list and find it very useful. It's definitely worth a print out to stick it inside your DVD or Blu-ray case.Thanks for reading now go get some!
summary: Here is a list of terms used on the show + subtitles are great.
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: When viewing, factor in that Evan Wright is a * journalist * for the the left-wing radical, hate-filled "Rolling Stone".
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: I never readGeneration Kill. I never watched the miniseries. But the members of a particular Internet forum I frequent wouldn't stop talking about it, so I rented it from Netflix. I was hooked from the first episode. Last week I finished the series and ordered the book. Before viewing the series, I had decided NOT to read the book, based on critical reviews by some military reviewers. The tone of the series didn't put me off, and I wanted to read the source material. Besides, I like to make my own decisions, and I made the right one for me.I did four years in a Marine infantry unit and went to the first Gulf War, so, not surprisingly, I have an interest in Marine Corps stories. I readJarhead: a Marine's Chronicle of the Gulf War and Other Battlesand liked it, because the author's experiences echoed my own. I enjoyed the movie adaptation, but there was an element of fantasy to it that caused me to keep it at arm's length, so to speak. It's the gritty realism of "Generation Kill" that really pulls me in.In terms of recreating my experiences, GK is scary-accurate. I wasn't with a recon unit and I didn't go into Iraq, but I dug my share of fighting holes and put up way more than my share of cammie nets, and I did my fair share of grousing about the Big Green [Machine]. The guys' sitting around and complaining about anything and everything--and particularly their officers--is spot-on. So if the officers come across as less than competent, it's because the story is told from the point of view of the enlisted men. No surprise there. The characters and their bickering and camaraderie really resonated with me, and by the end of the series I felt as if I knew the guys. LikeBand of Brothersbefore it, GK's casting is remarkable. Alexander Skarsgard is magnetic. And like Person says, "You're not gay if you think Rudy is hot."It will be many years before I can share this series with my son, but when he is old enough I will. It will give him a little taste of what the Corps was like before powered armor suits and smart weapons (that is, the broken ones handed down from the army). :)Update: I finished reading the book in about three days. It was solid, but I didn't feel as if it really gave me any more information or insight than the miniseries did. To me that says more about the strength of the series than it does about the book. I also bought Nate Fick's book,One Bullet Away: The Making of a Marine Officer. So there's that.
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: This HBO miniseries documents the adventures of a Marine platoon during the first phase of the Iraq War in 2003 as they rumble around the desert in unarmored humvees looking for the bad guys.  The large cast and the density of military jargon in the dialogue can make the story difficult to follow for civilians like me, but the resulting texture and authenticity more than makes up for it.  A rather clear picture of the muddled tactical situation and the platoon's variety of reactions to it gradually emerges, and repeated viewings are bound to reveal additional insights.  This exceptional film mostly eschews politics in the interest of showing us what the war looks like from the front lines.The entire cast is outstanding, but special mention goes to the actors who portray the crew of Bravo Company's lead vehicle, who come closest to being the stars of the show.  Alexander Skarsgard (who should have been cast in the upcoming Thor movie) portrays the cool, dependable Brad "Iceman" Colbert.  James Ransome is Corporal Josh Ray Person, the mouth-mouthed driver who has some really funny monologues.  Billy Lush is the chillingly dim-witted Lance Corporal Trombley, who gets off on the violence.
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: This series was one of the best I've seen on the current ongoing war.  I'm a VietNam Vet and my heart and prayers go out to the man and women serving and protecting our Country.  This is a must see.
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: This series is an accurate and engrossing depiction of combat in Iraq. The Marines are presented realistically, as neither heroes nor villains, but men doing their jobs. There are stoic idealists like Sgt. Colbert and borderline psychotics like Cpt. America, and everything in between. This is just like any military unit, or any group of people for that matter. Instead of idealizing war, Generation Kill simply gives viewers a glimpse of what it is really like. And by the same token, the series does not condemn warfare, as many documentaries and films are so tempted to do lately.War is frustrating for the individual soldier. Not just the Iraq War, but any war. Generation Kill does an excellent job of capturing this frustration. The Sergeant Major's obsession with the grooming standard is a perfect example of how military units often lose track of what their priorities should be. But in the Sergeant Major's defense, standards are set for a reason. And if you stop enforcing some, others will usually follow. In combat, small standards and procedures often determine whether people live or die.On a more technical note, the acting and writing in Generation Kill were very well done. Realistically portraying a soldier or marine is probably one of the most difficult roles for an actor. There are so many subtle nuances of being a soldier or marine, that without actually being one, it is hard to understand them. Generation Kill did a great job of training the actors to look and sound believable.I was in Iraq for 27 months, in 2005 and in 2007/2008, and I can attest that this series is about as accurate as you can get in a film. I am in the Army, but I worked pretty extensively with Marines during both of my tours, so I have a pretty decent knowledge of how they work. In the end, whether you are Army, Marine Corps, Navy, Air Force or any other armed service member, the Iraq experience is for the most part universal. At different times you feel a wide range of emotions, from disappointment and despair, to elation and nostalgia. And Generation Kill does a great job of bringing those feelings to the viewer in a realistic and respectful way.
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: Full of great characterizations with a compelling script and solid story-telling.  Action and intrigue in ample measure and even manages to surprise.
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: This series was incredibly well-produced and I'm looking forward to owning the DVD set when it's released. As many people are saying, "Support our troops - BRING THEM HOME!" (We need them to defend us against the Republicans!)
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: I devoured the book and devoured the DVD as well. I have watched the DVD at least three times since I purchased it. The only thing I feel I can add to the numerous reviews here is that I find the characterizations of the company commanders- "Captain America" and "Encino Man" as rather specious. In one scene  one of the Captains doesn't know what "danger close" means. I find this almost impossible to believe. First of all, all Marines go through infantry training (even fighter  pilots) and "danger close" is about as basic a concept as there is. Second, these particular officers were Recon Marines. Recon Marines are the Marine Corps equivalent of Special Forces.  Everyone- from the lowest enlisted to the most senior officers- who are Recon Marines endure several months of brutal, physically, intellectually and emotionally demanding  training- just to become a Recon Marine. There is no way a Captain does not know the meaning of "Danger Close".
summary: Excellent- except for the representation of some of the officers

Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: I love Band of Brothers and I was really interested to see the comparisons between these two series.  I've not been in the military, but I've heard that both are pretty true to the times and the people, and it's very interesting to see the differences between a relatively civilian military being thrust suddenly into a great world war vs a highly trained and professional force engaged against a primarily weak and ineffective enemy.
summary: Band of Brothers for a different war
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: Over the past 10 years or so I've become addicted to war movies. I've seen as many as I could. While there are a few very good ones, this is the only one that feels real. There are intense battle scenes. There are plenty of explosions. Plenty of suspenseful standoffs at gunpoint. But what makes it real is that the soldiers are not portrayed as heroes. They are portrayed as human beings, many of whom become conflicted by what they witness and by their own actions. They actually grow as their war continues, and some of them begin questioning their purpose in Iraq.What this particular unit went through and how they reacted to it in the opening days of the Iraq war was just amazing. How their actions, decision-making, clownig around and their deepest thoughts -- how their compassion -- was captured by a single print journalist was amazing. How their story was retold years later by filmmakers who weren't even there was once again amazing. You won't be able to stop talking about this DVD. And you won't be able to get it out of your head, either.
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: Wow!  Why didn't this get a second season?  From the makers of the Wire, this is amazing!  I am not the reviewer who will tell the story of a movie and kill it for everyone, I am the guy who will pimp a good show. So, if you are looking for an action pact show, where soldiers go to war and kill everything they see, doing heroic deeds and kicking butt, this isn't actually what you will get.  In fact this series has the opposite effect, taking the glory of war out of people's minds and showing the gritty, bureaucratic mess it can actually be.  Showing from the eyes of a well trained, overly qualified, special unit in the Marines who are sent out on missions that are not what they trained for because of the egos of their higher ranking officers.  This shows the horrors of war, how the people on the ground see things different from those who give the orders back at HQ.  If you enjoyed The Wire, you'll love this.  Like I said, this isn't an action packed show, it is a developing drama and like The Wire, it takes a bit of time to get to a point but it is all very much worth the time.
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: The series certainly seems to be authentic in it's jargon, soldier attitudes, sets and locale.  It just didn't click for me.
summary: Not What I had Hoped it would be.

Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: If you only watched Game of Thrones then you'd never think that HBO defines itself by tattooing the face of Obama on everything it produces. This is supposed to be uncorrected 'realism', which is a fraud because it fails to realize the context of its moral prerogatives, itself a classical failure of liberals. In fact that failure for circumspection is what defines their essence, the 'tolerant intolerance of intolerance'.I only was able to stomach 3 episodes. As far as the element of pure entertainment, this series is a complete bore. A deliberate bore because it enjoys being another ponderous, self-serving liberal commentary on 'America'. One could turn on NPR and get the exact same message for free, rather than paying the premium for Amazon prime or giving David Simon 30 dollars.Realism here consist of bland military platitudes, "when you leave the Marines you get your brain back". Jarhead language is abound. Everyone is ready to shoot a "raghead" and send the boiled skull back to his wife. And that is pretty much it for the first 3 episodes. There is an occasional superficial gloss on the nature of the human race and 'Hate', always a touchstone for pretentious liberals. Naturally, colored men, whom HBO categorically presents as incorruptible bastions of virtue, give these monologues to us.Elsewhere the series has a large preoccupation with the race-war in America, as does OZ and 'The Wire'. Commentary is delivered through the same hysterical, despairing, hand-wringing David Simon liberalism, the dominant liberalism of our time. There is your token white racist guy here, as in OZ, and he gets put in his place by big black men, as with OZ. The Token white racist guy in 'The Wire' I think is understood to be America simply, since liberals have a mental defect and believe the wrong white people are still in complete control of this country and are still actively pursuing extermination of all others. But 'Generation Kill' also believes this to be true, "the white man won't be denied" says the incorruptible black man during the invasion; the voice of peace, reason, righteousness--this angel. Yes, race-conscious, race-driven, unreconstructed white men are responsible for Iraq. Gays are also hated. Vote Barack.
summary: more baby-boomer liberalism from David Simon: not worth a dump
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: I thought this was a good series. However not as realistic as it should have been. Nowhere as many shoot outs as there should have been. The leadership was poor, and should have been fired sooner. The idiot of a Captain and his AK-47 shroud have been the first to go. The NCO's were the backbone of the series and they are the backbone of the Corps.
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: loved it
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: The story does a good job of bringing out the stress and anxiety of combat situations coupled by the shear boredom of down time.The HBO writers however are obsessed with the "F" word, and less meaningful dialogue.
summary: The story does a good job of bringing out the stress and anxiety of ...
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: Besides the racisim and lack of diversity the series was really good. The show prooved my point that we did more harm than good.
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: A superior drama with excellent dialogue (subtitles recommended) using the argot of the military grunt supplemented by the slang of the working man - afro american, "white" and spanish american - to an exquisite Shakespearian degree, complete with references galore to pop culture of the time - not excluding the pudenda of Jay Lo.  A high degree of verisimilitude as a consequence.  Excellent in depth characterization illuminated by substantive acting. The book was good but this is better. My son is an Iraq veteran (grunt) and this series covers all the bases: failed strategy, poor leadership, brilliant leadership, shia/sunni conflict, inappropriate role of the Recon marines where an arab speaking, social working, military skills soldiers are required. religion,the need for repair of infrastructure, chaos in Baghdad, absence of WMD, the contempt felt for USA by the world, abuse of civilians - all covered through the grunts POV, and I guess, the imbedded reporter, who flies off in the end leaving behind the Recon Marines, a highly trained, mainly intelligent group of very fit, skilled and mainly honourable group, watching a video replay of the events depicted in the series - Brad, ICE MAN, Sgt and leader, does not watch, and as the laptop show unfolds they all drift away from watching, with regret, sadness,disgust, who knows? and their so called enemy? children, women, old men, Syrian students. Indeed, the last 30 minutes of this series which includes the almost wordless leaving of the Rolling Stone reporter, is worth comparing with Greek Tragedy where the audience is left with a feeling of pity, awe and sadness particularly if we consider the Marine, as a noble symbol that has transformed the often chaotic lives of ordinary mainly working class boys into "noble warriors". What a waste of an amazing resource these men are. A brilliant series.
Title: Generation Kill

reviewerName: James L. Woolridge "Wooly in PSL, FL."
reviewText: Missed this mini-series on TV /HBO but thanks to PRIME watched it for free.  Beat that with a stick.  GENERATION KILL is one very outstanding show. Not filled with name stars but so well done.  We see the frustrations of war and the sad realities.  We see the total commitment our troops make for our freedom and the often felt snafu of leadership, as seen from the soldiers end.  These are our guys seen through real glasses.  Take the time to watch it.  You sure don't have to be a war fan.  EXCELLENT/HIGHLY RECOMMENDED
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: I had the opportunity to borrow this DVD set from a friend and was amazed by it.  It is absolutely worth watching ... That being said, I didn't think it was up to the caliber of The Pacific or Band of Brothers, but definitely worth watching - Beware it is quite graphic and heart wrenching in many parts!
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: I have seen numerous war films and TV series and was on the search for a more realistic version of the war. I have to admit that I hated this series in the beginning. I am by no means a prude but some of the things that were said even had me going Whoa! These guys are a**holes! But after that 1st episode, it grabbed my attention and never let go. I have never been in the military, but come from a military family, with my son being the latest recruit. This series showed the true grit, attitude, boredom, tediousness and, yes, bravery of a Marine's deployment. It was very interesting to see the various reactions to the same bad and sometimes horrifying circumstances. Some handled it by keeping it inside, some took it out on others, some became better men because of it. This series showed the dilemmas faced by these guys, the confusion that occurs during battle, the endless waiting that goes on, the frustration of waiting to receive permission to shoot the enemy, and the amazing way that most of them retain their sense of humor through it all. The one thing that really opened my eyes was imagining how these guys felt helping and herding the civilians through the streets and always wondering who or what may be concealing a bomb. Imagine helping these people carry their belongings (luggage, bags, etc.) never knowing if it was going to blow you to bits.I have the utmost respect for anyone, be it a Marine, soldier, or Airman, that has had to participate in this ugly war. I highly recommend this series to get a feel for what it's really like for our warriors over there.
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: Great programming, keeps you on the edge of your seat and really interesting for people who don't really have any idea what's gone on in Iraq.
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: Watched the series over the course of a couple of days. I was overwhelmed by the horror and the beauty of it and was furious and touched and confused and convicted by it. The rendering of the book was breathtaking. The acting was heartwrenching and brilliant. The ending was saved by the soundtrack. I will watch it again.
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: Although there was considerable dramatic license used to make the episodes more exciting, as a retired Marine Chief Warrant Officer (a gunnery sergeant before selection for warrant officer), I found a considerable amount of truth in the leadership and interaction of the Marines. The typical one or two incompetent officers quickly identified by the enlisted Marines but the senior battalion officers closed ranks and protected the incompetent officers. Enlisted Marines bearing the brunt of responsibility for their officers' mistakes - such as Captain America's attempted bayoneting of an Iraqi and Godfather's decision, quickly executed by the battalion sergeants major, to abandon a truck with a flat tire because Godfather wanted to impress the Commanding General. Later, Godfather learns the abandoned truck contained the battalion's MRE's, ammunition, and most importantly and unforgivable, the Battalion's battle streamers! Overall, I thoroughly enjoyed the series as the writing and the acting were generally top notch.
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: Generation Kill is more realistic than your average war film because it's more boring. Don't get me wrong--I was glued to the set for every minute of every episode. The series features strong characters, great dialogue, and no little action, and those traits make it watchable. And what the series gets absolutely right is the sheer boredom that military service sometimes entails. "Hurry up and wait," as they said during World War II or, as one of my college professors put it, "100 hours of boredom and one of sheer terror."Generation Kill is adapted from the book of the same name by Evan Wright, but it's clear that the writers and producers have also incorporated material from One Bullet Away, the memoir by Nathaniel Fick, whom viewers will recognize as a platoon commander in this series. (Both books, by the way, are excellent reading--Fick's is one of the best I've ever read.) The series follows a platoon of Marine recon from Kuwait through the initial invasion of Iraq. Along the way, firefights break out with hostile jihadists, the company is ambushed, sent on seemingly pointless missions, and eventually arrives in Baghdad itself. And like I said--I was hooked from the very beginning.If you're looking for a more realistic view of the war fought by modern grunts, or even just several hours of good entertainment, Generation Kill is the ticket.Recommended.
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: Having 2 military family member, this movie felt very real. Plus I love the humor and the relationship portrayed between the guys. Felt so real. Good story. Everyone in my family loves it.
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: I have this on both DVD and Blu Ray. I bought the blu ray because I wanted a sharper picture to go along with the upgraded sound. Honestly I don't think it was worth the money. The sound quality on the DVD version is just as good as the blu ray and the picture is almost the same. There's a slight upgrade in parts, but on the whole I felt like I was watching the DVD version when I had the blu ray in (most of it has the same grainy quality to it - not saying this is bad as it's the style it was shot in, just that it looks the same as the DVD), again, minus beefer sound quality, especially during the battle scenes.One thing that really set this version apart is losing the military glossary book from the DVD. It is included in this set, but it's interactive on the disks. To some that might not matter, but when I'm watching and want to look up a term, it's so much easier to just pull out the book and flip a few pages rather than interrupting the flow of the show by fussing with the remote. I enjoy the book so much I took it from the DVD set and put it into the blu ray set so I'd always have it handy.All in all, it's an good purchase if you're dead set on having a blu ray version, but if you don't have either, I'd still recommend getting the DVD version over the blu ray. It just doesn't offer enough to make it worth the additional money.
summary: Quality set, but if you have the DVD not worth the upgrade
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: Okay, when I first started watching this show I had to stop myself from either falling asleep or throwing something at the screen.  The "bro" and uber-homoerotic scenes added to the complete lack of action I had intended to sit down and watch, and were frustrating.  A lot of it seemed trite and obvious.Here's the thing though.  They nailed it.  First, the actors get a bit better at saying things like "bro," but, more importantly, the series as a whole gives one of the best portrayals of this war I've yet to encounter.  There is this rush to take down an enemy that is only sometimes there to fight, and the first episodes make you feel the frustration (not to say that I wish there had been more bloodshed in the war) and even boredom of the ready-to-do-this troops.  This slog continues, with moments, little glimpses of what is trying to be portrayed.  By the "end" of the series, mirroring the false end of the war, the pace and action pick up.  So one is left with the impression that the real fighting didn't even start until the end was declared.It can seem that the writers were at times trying to glamorize certain characters and character traits, but don't make the assumptions.  Watch this all the way through before passing judgement.  Characters aren't good or bad, they are all like-able and dislike-able in their own time, and the reality of that portrayal left me with the impression, but only by the end of the series, that I had seen something real.Kudos to the writers and producers of this show.  This may not be the most popular format for storytelling, and at times is difficult to get in to, but by the end they make it all work.
summary: Important: Do not give up on this show.
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: Based a book by an embedded reporter, Generation Kill is a ground level view of the invasion of Iraq seen through the eyes of young marines.Everyone goes in with the best of intentions but soon the stupidity of war is on full display, from medal-seeking officers, to incompetent NCOs, to callus soldiers.  Early on the unit is issued chemical warfare suits but in jungle colors rather than desert.  Later they're low on food and ammo after their commander abandons the supply truck to make better time.  In one chilling scene, the marines try to stop a car by firing a smoke grenade as a warning.  But the grenade misses, strikes a refugee in the head and kills him.  Their reaction is roughly equivalent to a child losing a video game.  Later a helicopter destroys an entire building in front of them; they react like they're watching a game.The attention to detail is incredible; you can even see the difference between the regulars and the reservists by their equipment.The script is subtle at times; a single line of dialogue explains very complex problems.  The jargon and curses are very thick, to the point where the package includes a glossary for civilians.The last few episodes are particularly interesting as the marines 'break character' and act more human.  Even the CO becomes much more sympathetic.I highly recommend it as a drama, as a war story and as an insight into the Iraq War.
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: Trash, crap, garbage, stinks, disgraceful, and any other words for pure JUNK. HBO should be ASHAMED & APOLOGIZE to our brave men & women in the US military for making this big piece of pure crap. But, I'm sure HBO received tons of praise (and money) from liberals & haters of our armed forces & this country. Don't waste your time watching this sorry excuse for a documentary.
summary: Minus Five Stars for Pure Garbage
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: This was a really good imitation of Marine life. The characters are likeable and believable. Lot of famous names in this too.
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: if you can get past the "F" bombs, and really, what do you expect from war movies, this series is great.  Rudy's  contributions helped to keep this historically accurate, and didn't gloss over the horrors of war that the Iraq people experienced.  It focused on the recon battalion and I enjoyed that.
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: Really interesting to hear what they really think - And what they talk about with each other. Couldn't help seeing how young they are and putting themselves in harm's way for their country.  They as a bunch are admirable.
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: This was incredible to watch! It was true-to-life and very well depicted. It's more in the lines of a *Documentary*  -- so if you want to watch a MOVIE...this is not for you. Personally...I really enjoyed it. It is about the everyday life of our deployed troops, to the Middle East. It made me appreciate our troops even more. My son served over there, twice. They call him "DOC" -- he was a Medic.
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: Not many of us give thought to what it must be like to be in combat, particularly in someplace like Iraq.  This series tells the story (based on the non-fiction book by Evan Wright) about a group that was on of the first on the scene in Iraq at the beginning.  Certainly a complex topic, but with many facets to it.  Not only does it show the war side of it, it shows the human side that those serving are faced with.  It's complex and rather gritty at times.  The series doesn't glorify war and there's no political slant to it.  It focuses on the marines and what goes with it.I actually started reading the book that this series was based on by Evan Wright before I started the series. The characters that were described so well in the book are brought to life on screen with a fabulous cast that is led by Alexander Skarsgard as Brad Colbert, Team Leader.  This series cetainly shows his range as an actor.  He's the "iceman" - calm, tough and calculating, but also shows humor, compassion and downright sadness at times.  We get many glimpses of him behind a large gun and what he conveys with his eyes nothing short of amazing.  Also James Rascone as Ray Person, Brad's Humvee driver and a great source of comic relief.  Sleep deprived and on "RipFuel", he's usually telling stories, making jokes or singing songs, but you see him a bit down a few times and he does that equally as well.  Stark Sands is excellent as Lt. Nathaniel Fick. His performance is a little more difficult to describe, but I can't imagine someone else cast in the same part.  His interactions with the entire cast are fantastic.The rest of the casting is great as well, but the 3 mentioned above were the most noteworthy.  I don't own any "series" DVD box sets, and this is my first.  Well worth the time.  If you like the series, check out the book that is was based upon.While the series follows the dialog almost verbatim most of the time, there are things in the book that are not in the series, as well as insights and more information about the marines in the series.  The book gives the information, while the series gives a visual and puts a face on the marines described.
summary: Great interpretation of the book based on -FABULOUS CASTING
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: Love this. Really does give an insight to being a marine on deployment. Recon talking Iraq? Even better. Must see.
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: In the spirit of "Band of Brothers" and "The Pacific," "Generation Kill" is an excellent ensemble performance, in addition to a revelation of the reality of recent modern military campaigns.  See the effects of detached policy decisions by more senior military officials and politicians.  This (mini-)series gently takes our military down from the pedestal on which we've placed them without destroying the regard we have for the grunts in the trenches.
summary: An Excellent View on the Second Gulf War
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: Loved Band of Brothers.  Wasn't such a fan of the Pacific.  Generation Kill is pretty darn good.  I'm not going to say it's better than Band of Brothers, because it's just not really the same thing.  But if you didn't like the Pacific because there wasn't enough character development, or you thought it spent too much time doing hollywood sex scenes... you'll love Generation Kill.It follows a group of young Recon Marines in the invasion of Iraq.  You'll get to know and love several of these characters and you'll be forced to experience all of the B-S that they did.  You'll laugh, you'll get pissed, you might even say w-t-f a couple times.  It's a great series.I was reading One Bullet Away when I bought this series on a whim.  Turns out, it's the same story.  They are great compliments to each other.
summary: Why didn't I see this sooner?
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: This is an excellent short series from HBO with a terrific cast. A couple of the guys play either themselves or a fictional Marine which speaks well of the general accuracy of the piece. The brutality of war, the confusion of this particular war (the invasion of Iraq), the brotherhood of men in combat -- all are well depicted and depicted pretty much without rose-colored glasses. These are Marines, not shiny perfect heroes. I recommend this series very highly.
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: Ep 7  @ around 45 mins..  "All this is a bomb".. how prophetic.. whoever that Iraqi minister was knew that this peace would never last.I have nothing else to say on this matter.. except thanks to our services for trying .
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: War is hell.  Moments of shear terror and long periods of boredom are well depicted here. The troops and there antics are not creditable however. This is not my Marine Corps. The in your face ineptitude of the officers/SrNCO  and there hubris is pure fiction and makes a mockery of the real deal.  Just another anti-War shootem up!  Semper Fi.
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: I love the show because I get all the jokes, and I can relate to everything. This is my own biased review.
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: I read the book before I watched the series.  I know it was all the rage on HBO when it came out, but I am usually late to the party and this time was no exception.  However, having said that, this isn't one of those times when the book was better than the series.  In fact, the series and the book not only go hand in hand, they actually do a lovely job of complimenting each other.  I think this could be because of the heavy involvement of the author, or it could just be that they had an extremely talented and dedicated group of actors.  Once you watch this, you will want to watch it again and again.  You get something different every time.
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: I'm a war film buff--or really more of a war film lover; "buff" sounds like I know what I'm talking about.  Generation Kill is not what I expected.  I thought it was going to be a documentary; then, I did some research and learned that it was based on a book by a Rolling Stones Magazine writer.It is vulgar, but it is young men in war.  I'm intrigued (dismayed) by the lack of respect that some of these young men have for those who support them, but I'm not surprised.Is it realistic?  How do I know?  The closest thing I've ever come to war is riding in a cargo plane coming back from the (then) Panama Canal Zone when I was in 3rd grade with my dad (now retired Army).The setting seems realistic; the characters seem realistic.  The plot moves along at a steady pace.What keeps from giving it 5 stars is that I can't decide if the characters "move" me.  I know that many of you will find that trite, but I watch television and movies to be entertained.  I want a personal connection to the characters (I like the same thing in books).I recommend that you at least watch the first episode, but it is NOT Band of Brothers.  The vulgarity is a bit shocking.  My 65-year-old mom would find it offensive.Melissa
summary: I like it; I'm still deciding if I love it
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: In my opinion it is hard to say anything less than superlative about GENERATION KILL.  This three CD set is a definite GO-TO when I need an action thriller, second, so far, only to the Bourne Trilogy.Marines of the First Recon Battalion arrive in Iraq in 2003 and I will not tell you anything about the plot.  Suffice it to say that you are embedded with these Marines in every respect and your physical presence is in the lead Hum-V in the person of a reporter from Rolling Stone Magazine.Each member of this team is unique and the casting could not have been better.Do not sit down to watch GENERATION KILL thinking that you'll see one or two chapters a night.  Forget that.  You will compulsively watch all seven chapters with an annoying need to know if certain individuals will get what's coming to them.Among other feelings you will be pissed-off and glad that your tour is over.  When the First Recon Marines go home, you will go to bed happy that you are out of Iraq.
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: I read the book as soon as it came out, enjoyed the read, and then forgot about it. So I almost fell off my chair when I heard that it would be turned into a TV series with some of the Marines actually playing roles in it. Awesome! The series turned out to be a perfect supplement to both Evan Wright's account of the invasion and Nathaniel Fick's book ("One Bullet Away"). The actors are excellent - this is what made Alexander Skarsgard's career take off. It's entertaining as hell, but it also shows you what happens to innocent civilians when their country gets invaded. I'd like to watch it again, but I would have to cut out all the disturbing stuff first. Most of it involves the Iraqi population.The invasion of Iraq was a tragic error, and we're going to pay for it for a very long time.
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: I found the trend of representational dialogs exceedingly more liberal from WW1 through this period.  Typical FUBAR officer planning and  stupid tactics which were reflective of all wars serving little purpose. Good historical value.
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: Could never watch it again. Its good, sometimes a bit schmaltzy, sometimes raw.Much better than that piece of X Hurt Locker. This was realistic of what the invasion was like. god, seeing them wear NBC gear made me quiver
summary: Realistic, not the easist to watch
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: Much better than I thought it would be. Give it s look.  What happened here is alot like Vietnam, overall experience wise.We never learn
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: well done, very techie and vernacular oriented adds to reality as does the absence of formulaic scripting.Educational, view and study as you literally participate in the unit's patrols and down times.Worth viewing again to see what new can be learned.
summary: embedded spectators and learners seating available
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: Testosterone is the star of this Iraq War tell all.  The Marines are John Wayne all right, so Western Civilization will probably survive. Their enemy over there, it doesn't matter - the bad guys lose. That's the way it is - Hoora!My complements to HBO, Rolling Stone, and Evan Wright, they are so against The War, being card carrying Lefties and all, but they subdued their instincts long enough to actually tell some truths. True, Iraq is not Iwo Jima, but the opponent is savage enough.  Did these men understand the war?  Again, it doesn't matter, true warriors kill the bad guys with a minimum of collateral damage. Sigh!
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: I was a bit disappointed with this series.  Yes, the locations were great, South Africa is a dead ringer for Iraq, and the special effects were brilliant...BUT, I felt that there wasn't enough action.  Very few battle sequences, and those that there were, were too short.  The series spent way too much time with the internal politics of the military chain of command and how individual soldiers dealt with it.  I realize that the series was based on the writings and henceforth the book of the embedded Rolling Stone reporter that was featured in the series, but I must say that the fictional FX series "Over There" was much more exciting.That said, the portrayal of the first few weeks of the Iraq invasion was great.  From the MOP levels and the chaos in Baghdad after liberation was great.  So with that I give the series two stars, one for the location shooting, and one for the special effects.  I'd love to it it more stars, but quite frankly I would closely watch the show just waiting for something to happen, and then nothing ever did.If HBO, or whoever wanted to make a much more exciting show about the invasion, they should have used 3rd I.D. stuff, instead of a Marine Force Recon unit that *sighe* never got to do any force recon, other than once during the Nasiriyah sequence.
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: I watched Band of Brothers, then the Pacific.I notice at the end of Pacific, they showed all the soldiers and told a bit about there lives,and what year they died.  I am glad that the heroic soldiers of WW2 passed before they could see what the world has come to now.They would  be incredibly sad to see what people call themselves marines this day and time.No morality, no respect, and most of all, severely undertrained officers, who would send even more sadly deficient punks on a mission that they knew was a suicide ,..and just shrug their shoulders and call it acceptable casualties, only to be pinned with a metal for doing their job,..If the soldiers and the actions of these soldiers in this movie were true to what is real this day,?,....then it is a disgrace to what used to be the armed forces, and even more a disgrace to make a movie that portrays such ignorance and associate it with this country.If you notice,...no Spielberg or Hanks tag on this film,...most likely would have had nothing to do with producing two star crap like this.I am, ...and always will be proud to be an American, but it is sickening some of the tiny ball boys, this country produced after 1980."Generation Fools"I proudly submit,............and if my review makes you mad,.. then you are truly one of them.
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: Compared to other HBO favorites, e.g. The Pacific and Band of Brothers, I found this Iraq invasion mini-series most interesting because of the contrast of the American fighting military man from today compared to the 1940's.  65 years ago, with the draft, and a sense of duty, the "kids" were much more likely to follow orders without question.  The sadness I felt for today's military doing tours in Iraq & Afghanistan is the soldiers that want to make a difference to the people there are unable.  Usually because of incompetent leadership which comes with using reserves and national guardsmen.  Yes I am a vet from Vietnam-era, and though higher-ups like the concept of an all-voluntary force, I see a real drop-off in the quality of leadership.  All of this is brought out extremely well in this well-made HBO mini series, which I recommend but at a lower rating than the ones mentioned above.
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: This is one of David Simon's best works! No one in modern TV is catching real life stories, the feel and the look like David Simon. This story is based on the reporting and the book of Rolling Stone embedded reporter Evan Wright. Evan  tells the tale of riding with the 1st Recon Marines as they spearhead the invasion of Iraq (2003 the wrong war). With the help of wright Simon tells a story each episode of how the men react to the difficult surroundings as they move forward. He tells the stories of the frustrations, the no equipment, bad decisions by superiors. When the show closes we see the majority are tired and want to go home just to let these people figure life out on their own.
summary: The True Telling of How F uped the Invasion of Iraq (2003) was.
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: GOD BLESS THE CORPS!!Brilliant HBO Series on the good/bad of danger-close combat .. ..For those who say this series is 'sad' and/or horrific, it is to a small extent, but that is what warfare brings and the innocent will always die with the guilty .. .. It is unavoidable .. .. Yet, far more innocents die in peacetime - Think Darfur and North Korea .. ..As for the characters portrayed in the series - Did you feel some were unsavory and/or a bit warped?? Well .. ..Have you ever been in a HS/College/Pro sports locker room? Enough said .. ..In the end, it takes a SPECIAL person to place yourself in harm's way, and an even MORE SPECIAL person to join the Corps .. ..GOD BLESS ALL OF YOU AND THOSE WHO SERVE!SEMPER FI
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: Good acting, excellent story.  Definitely worth watching again and again.  Details of the Marine Corps are spot on.  Don't miss it.
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: The war in Iraq, as told and seen from their inbedded reporter from Rolling Stone magazine. The book was excellent and this HBO mini series holds a very close candle to the characters and story held within its pages.An excellent mix of sadness reality and comedic relief. Totally worth the watch.
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: An excellent boots on the ground war movie without the political crap that has polluted most of the middle east conflict productions.
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: Was entertaining for me...lots of swearing and comedy only found when a group of men have to deal with each other everyday.  Was intrigued that no one dies in their squad.
summary: LOL if you like dirty movies
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: First off let me say that if you have not read Generation Kill and Band of Brothers then you need to quit reading this review and get these books and read them.  Then watch the movies.  Both books are excellent (and both mini series are excellent too).  Generation Kill does an excellent job of capturing the environment of the Iraq confrontation.  The cast is perfect.  Band of Brothers suffered from a few miss casts like David Schwimmer.  I highly recommend this mini-series.
summary: If you like Band of Brothers you will like this.
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: "Generation Kill"  is a seven-part mini-series that looks at the first 40 days of the Iraq War as seen through the eyes of the elite U.S. First Reconnaissance Marines who were at the forefront of the invasion.  We see the barren landscape of Iraq, where the military often have to improvise their plans because of unexpected obstacles.  We see the confusion caused by a nonuniformed enemy that is able to blend easily in with civilians, and feel the never-ending tension they feel.  The documentary shows how the men of the First Recon Battalion combine their skill, resolve, humor, and dedication to do the work they are assigned and survive day after day.  What makes the film so involving is that it puts faces and personalities on the men who fight America's wars.  Bonus features include a roundtable discussion with members of the First Recon Marines led by Evan Wright, author of "Generation Kill;" a making-of featurette; six audio commentaries; deleted dialogues; and an insert with military glossary, chain of command chart, and mission map.
summary: Mini Series Looks at Early Days of Iraq War
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: Seemed pretty realistic.  Showed the "Fog of War" and how politics can get in the way of getting things done in the military.  Realistic battle scenes.
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: War which is a pure, insane act of violence...This is, without doubt, one of the most honest portrayals of what war is really like. War sucks... People go off to foreign places to kill other people, or to get killed. And they do all this in the name of "freedom," which is just a word that comes out of a can in much the same way Spam does. The soldiers in Iraq and Afghanistan are not fighting for our freedom. They are there because the government sent them there, and - like I did - went very often for the adventure. The ones who think they are "fightin' for our freedom" are merely naive.That being said, the character portrayals are very realistic, and the representation of war - of battle - of deadly conflict is very accurate, except that it is shown from just one perspective. The references to "they are the bad guys" is ironic insofar as we (including me) would do the same thing as those "bad guys" if foreign invaders dared to set foot on our shores.I liked the characters, and the honesty. I liked the bravado of those who sought to put this on air. I liked the settings, and the realism. I did not like the gratuitous violence, but this is a fact of war, and my dislike for it is personal, and something that got much too close to home, having seen it first hand. In the balance; had I not thought it well done and honest I would have simply stopped watching it. Unfortunately, though I am from a different era, and a different kind of war, it still took me back in time to where it shook me up from time to time.  I gave it four stars because of its quality, and took one away because it hit a few too many soft spots for me - no fault of the production. Would I watch the series again? No... I have enough reality in my everyday life without taking on old memories from another reality in a life lived long ago.War sucks...
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: Great show. I'm not necessarily pro war, but I like true war stories like this that show the good and the bad on both sides.
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: Ive watched this show a few times.  HBO does a good job, no matter what the naysayers nay.  I love mini-series because they can fit in more than if the whole show attempted to fit into a 2 hour movie.  Some things may not be "accurate" enough for everybody, but all in all it is a good deal.
summary: HBO has a good stable of actors
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: If you're a former or active duty Marine, you'll recognize the Marine Corps culture immediately, while watching "Generation Kill." The series captures how men see their roles in the ranks they hold and the responsibilities that come with it. Set in the Iraq invasion during Desert Storm, a battalion of elite Force Recon Marines charge into Iraq aboard their Humvies to achieve their objectives. Their leader, Lt.Colonel Stephen Ferrando, who calls himself "God Father" and earned the moniker due to his voice, as a result of throat cancer; tries to keep his unit in the forefront of the Marine Corps command by continuing to request new missions. It's very entertaining watching the "God Father" and his merry band of officers and senior NCOs imposing their nonsense on the average guys in the battalion. The biggest joke and jerk of course is Battalion Sergeant Major John Sixta, who runs around mandating that men adhere to strict Marine Corps regulations in the middle of a war. He embarrasses himself by dropping "God Father's" name time and again to give what says credibility. Of course, there are incompetent officers, who should never lead anyone anywhere as well as the ass kissing senior NCOs, who front for these boobs, and eventually get people killed with their orders.All the fun in the series is found inside Sgt. Brad Colbert's Humvee, where his driver, Cpl. Josh Ray Pearson; never stops talking and/or singing to the delight of the audience. Rolling Stones reporter Evan Scribe Wright is embedded into Colbert's squad, and acts as a sound board for Pearson's antics. Contributing to the hilarious banter is Sgt. Antonio Espera, who keeps reminding one and all about the White Man's Burden. Humor keeps these men from addressing the carnage unfolding all around them.A poignant point revealed time and again is that the war is just a vehicle for officers and senior NCOs to promote their careers, usually at the expense of the men serving under them. It really brings up the question for many who did serve in the Marine Corps at one time or another: now, why did I enlist into this all this tom foolery? You'd have to be a former Marine to fully appreciate the answer to that question.
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: Great miniseries based on a great book.  Perfect representation of OIF 1 and the uncertainty that came with the initial invasion.  Great actors brought the book to life.
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: It arrived earlier than expected and I had no problems with the discs.  I wasn't sure what to expect from this film since I had never seen it when it was on HBO.  The best Iraq war film I've seen yet and does a great job telling a story of what it must have been like on the front lines.The dialog was entertaining and sometimes funny, the characters were realistic, the scenes made it look like we were embedded with them, and there was enough action to keep me interested.  This is one that shouldn't be missed.
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: This came on HBO and I thought, well it's not necessarily my thing but why not? It gives an insight from the soldiers point of view into the US invasion to Iraq in 2003. I thought it was more realistic portrayal compared to others I have seen in this Genre. The casting was excellent, it blended actors with actual soldiers who took part in the invasion. I have to say, it totally sucked me right in. I watched the remainder of the episodes AND then I bought the series. Time well spent!!
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: Holy COW!!! Absolutely awesome. Seems TV has taken over for the last few years as the indomitable form of screen genius so many of "us" with taste have been craving for so long. It also seems that TV has finally given "us" who appreciate this a much fuller view of characters, plots, realistic scenic moments, etc... Hoorah for this series. More than 5 stars is deserved!!!Wolfy :)
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: Very well done series about the confusion of war and its impacts on the young soldiers who are often the pawns stuck in the middle.  By the time the series ended, I was fully invested in the characters and their storylines - was sad it was over!
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: I was expecting a lot more from this. You end up not liking many of the characters. Looks awesome but doesn't deliver.
Title: Generation Kill

reviewText: Reminded me of the total chaos of military operations and complete lack of communication from the top ranks to the PFC's.
Title: Generation Kill
